gen_chem.q: A weak acid has Ka = 1×10⁻⁵. What is its pKa?
Which element has the highest electronegativity?
gen_chem.exp: Fluorine is the most electronegative element (EN = 4.0 on the Pauling scale). [AAMC FC 5A]

gen_chem.q: At STP, one mole of an ideal gas occupies:
gen_chem.exp: At STP (0 °C, 1 atm), 1 mol ideal gas occupies 22.4 L — the molar volume. [AAMC FC 5E]

gen_chem.q: A buffer has maximum effectiveness when:
gen_chem.exp: Henderson-Hasselbalch: pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA]). When pH = pKa the ratio is 1:1, giving maximum buffering capacity. [AAMC FC 5B]

gen_chem.q: Which quantum number determines the shape of an orbital?
gen_chem.exp: Angular momentum quantum number l defines shape: l=0 (s), l=1 (p), l=2 (d), l=3 (f). [AAMC FC 5A]

gen_chem.q: Le Chatelier's principle states that a system at equilibrium will:
gen_chem.exp: When stress is applied (concentration, pressure, temperature change), the system shifts to oppose that change. [AAMC FC 5E]

gen_chem.q: A solution with [OH⁻] = 1×10⁻³ M has a pH of:
Which thermodynamic condition guarantees spontaneity at ALL temperatures?
gen_chem.exp: ΔG = ΔH − TΔS. If ΔH < 0 and ΔS > 0, ΔG is always negative (spontaneous) regardless of temperature. [AAMC FC 5E]

gen_chem.q: In a galvanic (voltaic) cell, oxidation occurs at the:
gen_chem.exp: OIL RIG / AN OX: Anode = Oxidation; Cathode = Reduction. In galvanic cells, the anode is the negative electrode. [AAMC FC 5C]

gen_chem.q: Using Henderson-Hasselbalch, what [A⁻]/[HA] ratio gives pH = 5.76 for acetic acid (pKa = 4.76)?
gen_chem.exp: pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA]) → 5.76 = 4.76 + log(x) → log(x) = 1 → x = 10. [AAMC FC 5B]

gen_chem.q: Which condition prevents calcium phosphate from precipitating in a protein urine test?
gen_chem.exp: Calcium phosphate precipitates at high pH. Maintaining neutral pH keeps it soluble, preventing false positives. [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 3]

gen_chem.q: Adding a common ion to a saturated solution will:
gen_chem.exp: The common ion effect: adding an ion already in the equilibrium shifts it left (Le Chatelier), decreasing solubility. Ksp itself is unchanged. [AAMC FC 5E]

gen_chem.q: The oxidation state of chromium in K₂Cr₂O₇ is:
Boiling point elevation is a colligative property, meaning it depends on:
opts: The molecular weight of the solute
gen_chem.exp: Colligative properties (bp elevation, fp depression, osmotic pressure) depend only on the NUMBER of solute particles, not their identity. ΔTb = iKbm. [AAMC FC 5B]

gen_chem.q: Which process releases the most energy per mole?
gen_chem.exp: Combustion reactions are highly exothermic (ΔH ≈ −890 kJ/mol for CH₄). Phase changes and dissolution are much less energetically significant. [AAMC FC 5E]

opts: Primary substrates in polar aprotic solvents
org_chem.exp: SN2 requires backside attack: primary substrates minimize steric hindrance; polar aprotic solvents don't solvate the nucleophile. [AAMC FC 5D]

org_chem.q: Which carbon functional group is most oxidized?
org_chem.exp: Carboxylic acid (–COOH) has carbon at oxidation state +3 — the highest of these options. [AAMC FC 5D]
CIP rules rank substituents by atomic number. If priority decreases clockwise with lowest priority pointing away = R; counterclockwise = S. [AAMC FC 5D]

org_chem.q: What functional group forms when two amino acids join at a peptide bond?
org_chem.exp: Peptide bond: carboxyl of one AA + amine of another → amide (–CO–NH–) + water lost. This is an AAMC Sample Question (Skill 1). [AAMC FC 5D]

opts: Tertiary substrates in polar protic solvents
org_chem.exp: SN1 forms a carbocation intermediate. Tertiary carbocations are most stable (3 alkyl groups donate e⁻). Polar protic solvents stabilize the ionic transition state and carbocation. [AAMC FC 5D]

org_chem.q: E2 elimination requires which geometry between the leaving group and β-hydrogen?
org_chem.exp: E2 is a concerted one-step mechanism requiring anti-periplanar (180°) alignment for proper orbital overlap between the C–H and C–LG bonds. [AAMC FC 5D]

org_chem.q: Which reagent selectively reduces aldehydes and ketones but NOT esters?
org_chem.exp: NaBH₄ is a mild, selective hydride donor that reduces only aldehydes and ketones. LiAlH₄ is more powerful and reduces all carbonyls including esters and acids. [AAMC FC 5D]

org_chem.q: In ¹H NMR, a carboxylic acid –OH proton appears at approximately:
org_chem.exp: Carboxylic acid OH protons are highly deshielded by the adjacent C=O, appearing at ~10–12 ppm — the most downfield common proton signal. [AAMC FC 5D]

org_chem.q: Enantiomers are identical in all physical properties EXCEPT:
org_chem.exp: Enantiomers rotate plane-polarized light equally but in opposite directions (+/−). All other physical properties are identical in achiral environments. [AAMC FC 5D]

org_chem.q: OsO₄ reacts with an alkene to form:
org_chem.exp: OsO₄ adds two OH groups to the same face of the double bond (syn addition) → syn-diol (vicinal diol). [AAMC FC 5D]

org_chem.q: Which statement about aldehydes vs. ketones is correct?
opts: Ketones are more reactive toward nucleophilic addition
Aldehydes have a carbonyl on a terminal carbon and are more reactive
Ketones and aldehydes have equal reactivity
org_chem.exp: Aldehydes (–CHO) are terminal and more electrophilic/reactive than ketones. Aldehydes can be further oxidized to carboxylic acids; ketones cannot. [AAMC FC 5D]

org_chem.q: IR spectroscopy is most useful for:
opts: Identifying functional groups via bond vibrations
org_chem.exp: IR spectroscopy detects characteristic bond stretching/bending vibrations (fingerprints for functional groups). Key peaks: C=O ~1700 cm⁻¹, O–H ~3300 cm⁻¹. [AAMC FC 5D]

physics.q: If resistance doubles and voltage stays constant, current:
physics.exp: Ohm's Law: V = IR. If R doubles and V is constant, I = V/R is halved. [AAMC FC 5C]

physics.q: A projectile launched horizontally has zero initial:
physics.exp: Horizontal launch → vertical initial velocity = 0. Gravity immediately provides downward acceleration (g = 9.8 m/s²). Horizontal and vertical motions are independent. [AAMC FC 4A]
Myopia: parallel rays focus in front of the retina. Concave (diverging) lenses spread light, shifting the focal point back onto the retina. [AAMC FC 4D]

physics.q: The unit of electric potential difference is:
physics.exp: Voltage = electric potential difference, measured in Volts (V = J/C — joules per coulomb). [AAMC FC 5C]

physics.q: Sound travels fastest through which medium?
physics.exp: Sound requires a medium and travels faster through denser/stiffer materials: steel (~5000 m/s) > water (~1500 m/s) > air (~343 m/s). Cannot travel through vacuum. [AAMC FC 4C]

opts: Force × displacement in direction of force
physics.exp: W = Fd·cosθ. Work is done only when force has a component in the direction of displacement. [AAMC FC 4A]

physics.q: The First Law of Thermodynamics states:
opts: Energy cannot be created or destroyed
Heat flows from cold to hot
physics.exp: First Law: ΔU = q + w. The total energy of an isolated system is conserved; energy is only transferred or converted. [AAMC FC 5E]

physics.q: According to Bernoulli's principle, as fluid flows into a narrower tube:
physics.exp: Bernoulli: P + ½ρv² + ρgh = constant. Smaller area → higher velocity (continuity) → lower pressure. This explains airfoil lift and venturi effects. [AAMC FC 4B]

physics.q: The continuity equation (A₁v₁ = A₂v₂) for incompressible fluids means:
opts: Flow rate decreases in a narrower tube
Velocity increases in a narrower tube
Pressure increases in a narrower tube
Velocity decreases in a wider tube only
physics.exp: Continuity: Q = Av is constant. Smaller cross-section → higher velocity. This is why blood moves faster in large vessels than across all capillaries combined (collectively they have huge total area). [AAMC FC 4B]

physics.q: An ambulance approaches you sounding its siren. The pitch you hear is:
physics.exp: Doppler effect: approaching source compresses wavefronts → shorter wavelength → higher frequency/pitch. As it moves away, pitch drops. [AAMC FC 4C]

physics.q: The photoelectric effect shows that electrons are ejected only when light:
opts: Has sufficient intensity regardless of frequency
Is reflected off the metal surface
Has wavelengths in the visible spectrum only
physics.exp: Einstein: photoelectric effect proves light consists of photons (quanta). Electron ejection depends on photon energy (E = hf), not intensity. Below threshold frequency, no ejection occurs regardless of brightness. [AAMC FC 5A]

physics.q: After 3 half-lives, what fraction of a radioactive sample remains?
physics.exp: Each half-life: half remains. (1/2)¹ = ½, (1/2)² = ¼, (1/2)³ = ⅛. After 3 half-lives, 12.5% remains. [AAMC FC 5A]

physics.q: Poiseuille's Law states that blood flow rate through a vessel is most sensitive to:
opts: Radius of the vessel (to the 4th power)
physics.exp: Q = πr⁴ΔP / (8ηL). Flow is proportional to r⁴ — doubling the radius increases flow 16-fold. This is why arterial constriction/dilation has profound effects on blood flow. [AAMC FC 4B]

biochem.q: Which bonds hold together the two strands of DNA?
biochem.exp: Hydrogen bonds between complementary base pairs (A–T: 2 H-bonds; G–C: 3 H-bonds) hold the two strands together. G–C pairs are stronger. [AAMC FC 1A]

biochem.q: Km represents the substrate concentration at:
biochem.exp: Km = [S] when v = ½Vmax. Lower Km = higher affinity. Km is an intrinsic property of the enzyme-substrate pair. [AAMC FC 1A]

biochem.q: Which process generates the most ATP per glucose molecule?
biochem.exp: Oxidative phosphorylation via the ETC generates ~28–32 ATP, compared to glycolysis (2 net ATP). The ETC uses NADH and FADH₂ to drive ATP synthase. [AAMC FC 3B]

biochem.q: Primary protein structure is defined as:
biochem.exp: Primary structure = the sequence of amino acids linked by peptide bonds. It determines all higher-order structures. [AAMC FC 1A]

biochem.q: Which molecule is the cell's universal energy currency?
biochem.exp: ATP (adenosine triphosphate) powers virtually all cellular processes. Its hydrolysis (ATP → ADP + Pᵢ) releases ~7.3 kcal/mol. [AAMC FC 3A]

biochem.q: Fatty acid beta-oxidation occurs in the:
biochem.exp: Beta-oxidation in the mitochondrial matrix sequentially cleaves 2-carbon units (acetyl-CoA) from fatty acids, generating NADH and FADH₂ per cycle. [AAMC FC 3B]

biochem.q: Competitive inhibition affects enzyme kinetics by:
biochem.exp: Competitive inhibitor binds the active site, competing with substrate → apparent Km increases (lower affinity). Excess substrate can outcompete the inhibitor, so Vmax is unchanged. [AAMC FC 1A]

biochem.q: Net ATP yield from glycolysis (cytoplasm, per glucose) is:
biochem.exp: Glycolysis: 4 ATP produced − 2 ATP invested = net 2 ATP + 2 NADH + 2 pyruvate per glucose. [AAMC FC 3B]

biochem.q: Each acetyl-CoA entering the TCA cycle generates:
biochem.exp: Per turn of the TCA cycle: 3 NADH + 1 FADH₂ + 1 GTP (= ATP equivalent) + 2 CO₂ released. [AAMC FC 3B]

biochem.q: At physiological pH 7.4, the alpha-amino group of a free amino acid exists as:
biochem.exp: Amino group pKa ≈ 9. At pH 7.4 (below pKa), the amino group is protonated: –NH₃⁺. Carboxyl group (pKa ≈ 2) is deprotonated: –COO⁻. [AAMC FC 5D]

biochem.q: Low pH shifts the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right (Bohr effect), meaning:
opts: Hemoglobin releases O₂ more readily to tissues
The curve shifts left in exercising muscle
biochem.exp: Bohr effect: high CO₂/H⁺ (low pH) stabilizes the T-state (low-affinity) hemoglobin → O₂ released to active tissues. Curve shifts right = lower O₂ affinity. [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 4; FC 3B]

biochem.q: NAD⁺ functions in cellular catabolism as:
biochem.exp: NAD⁺ (oxidized form) accepts 2 electrons + 1 H⁺ → NADH (reduced). NADH then donates electrons to Complex I of the ETC, driving ATP synthesis. [AAMC FC 3B]

biochem.q: Which type of enzyme inhibition changes Vmax but NOT Km?
biochem.exp: Noncompetitive inhibitors bind an allosteric site (not the active site) regardless of substrate. They reduce Vmax (fewer functional enzyme molecules) but do not affect Km (substrate binding is unaffected). [AAMC FC 1A]

cars_comp.q: In CARS, identifying the author's main argument primarily helps you:
opts: Anchor all other questions to a central thesis
cars_comp.exp: The central claim is the interpretive anchor. Every tone, inference, and application question should be evaluated against it. [AAMC CARS Skill 1]

cars_comp.q: When a CARS passage uses 'plausible' rather than 'certain,' this signals:
opts: Hedged, qualified support — not absolute commitment
The point is irrelevant to the argument
cars_comp.exp: Hedge words (plausible, may, suggests, arguably, could) indicate the author is presenting a qualified position — a critical tonal cue on CARS. [AAMC CARS Skill 1]

cars_comp.q: 'Which answer is MOST supported by the passage?' requires you to:
opts: Select the most universally true statement
Select the choice best grounded in passage evidence
cars_comp.exp: CARS is 100% passage-based. The correct answer must be directly supported or implied by the passage text — never by outside knowledge. [AAMC CARS Skill 1]

cars_comp.q: The author's tone is best identified through:
opts: The subject matter of the passage
Word choice, qualifiers, and how opposing views are framed
Whether the author uses first person
cars_comp.exp: Tone = language choices. Look for evaluative adjectives, rhetorical questions, sarcasm, hedges, and how the author characterizes opposing ideas. [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

cars_comp.q: 'Application' questions in CARS ask you to:
opts: Apply the author's logic or principles to a new situation
Identify the author's implicit assumptions only
cars_comp.exp: Application questions extend the author's logic to scenarios not discussed in the passage. The author's reasoning (not your own opinion) guides the answer. [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

cars_comp.q: When asked for the author's 'primary purpose,' the best answer:
opts: Describes a specific detail from one paragraph
Reflects the overarching goal of the entire passage
Identifies a fact in the opening sentence only
cars_comp.exp: Primary purpose = the big-picture goal across the whole passage. Not a detail, not outside info — what was the author trying to accomplish overall? [AAMC CARS Skill 1]

cars_comp.q: A CARS answer that goes 'beyond the scope' of the passage is wrong because:
opts: It introduces claims not supported or implied by the passage
It uses language from the passage
cars_comp.exp: CARS demands passage grounding. Choices that import plausible-sounding but unsupported external ideas are always wrong, even if factually true in the real world. [AAMC CARS Skill 1]

cars_comp.q: When two answer choices seem equally correct, the tie-breaker is:
opts: Choose the one matching outside knowledge
Which is more directly supported by specific passage text
cars_comp.exp: Ask: 'Can I point to the passage text that supports this?' The answer better grounded in specific evidence is correct. CARS never rewards outside knowledge. [AAMC CARS Skill 1]

cars_comp.q: The difference between 'inference' and 'stated fact' in CARS is:
opts: Stated facts appear verbatim; inferences are logical conclusions not explicitly stated
cars_comp.exp: Stated facts are directly written. Inferences are conclusions the author implies but does not explicitly state — still grounded in the passage. [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

cars_comp.q: In CARS, the passage's structure (e.g., 'compare/contrast,' 'problem/solution') helps because:
opts: It tells you the author's educational background
It reveals how the author organizes and supports the main argument
It determines the correct answer automatically
cars_comp.exp: Recognizing passage structure (argument, narrative, analysis, compare/contrast) helps you predict where key information is and how the author builds the central claim. [AAMC CARS Skill 1]

cars_arg.exp: Ad hominem attacks the person rather than the argument's logic or evidence — a core CARS logical fallacy. [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

cars_arg.q: Which most effectively strengthens a causal claim?
cars_arg.exp: Causation requires eliminating confounds. Ruling out alternative causes is the strongest support for a causal claim — correlation alone never establishes causation. [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

opts: Misrepresenting an argument to attack a weaker version
cars_arg.exp: Straw man: distort the opponent's actual argument into an easier-to-attack version, then defeat that instead. This avoids engaging the real claim. [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

cars_arg.q: A deductively valid argument is one where:
opts: The conclusion follows necessarily if the premises are true
cars_arg.exp: Validity is about structure, not truth: if the premises WERE true, the conclusion MUST follow. An argument can be valid but have false premises (unsound). [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

cars_arg.q: Which is an example of circular reasoning?
opts: 'Clinical trials demonstrate this drug is effective'
'The Bible is true because the Bible says so'
'Most experts agree, so it is likely correct'
'If A causes B and B causes C, then A causes C'
cars_arg.exp: Circular reasoning (begging the question): the conclusion is smuggled into the premise — 'the Bible is true because the Bible says so' assumes what it intends to prove. [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

cars_arg.q: Which correlation is most consistent with the bystander effect?
opts: More bystanders → less time before someone helps
More bystanders → more time before someone helps
Fewer bystanders → more time before someone helps
Number of bystanders is unrelated to helping behavior
cars_arg.exp: Bystander effect (Darley & Latané): more bystanders → greater diffusion of responsibility → longer response time. Positive correlation between # bystanders and response delay. [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 4; FC 7B]

cars_arg.q: What does Bourdieu's 'cultural capital' concept predict?
opts: Youth culture will be most valued
Cultural practices converge with better communication
Class-based cultural distinctions diminish during recessions
Cultural distinctions of elite classes will be more socially valued
cars_arg.exp: Cultural capital: knowledge, behaviors, and tastes of dominant/elite classes are institutionally valued and reproduced — perpetuating social stratification. [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 2; FC 10A]

opts: Only two options when more exist
cars_arg.exp: False dichotomy/dilemma: oversimplifies a complex issue into exactly two options (e.g., 'you're either with us or against us'), ignoring other possibilities. [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

cars_arg.q: Which best describes the fallacy of 'appeal to authority'?
opts: Using an expert's opinion as definitive proof even when outside their expertise
Assuming two things that correlate are causally related
cars_arg.exp: Appeal to authority: citing an authority figure as conclusive evidence, especially when their expertise doesn't apply to the specific claim. Expertise within a field is relevant; outside it is fallacious. [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

cars_arg.q: In CARS, to weaken an argument you must find evidence that:
opts: Makes the conclusion less likely to be true given the premises
Is unrelated to the passage topic
cars_arg.exp: Weakening an argument: find evidence that undermines the premise, breaks the logical connection, or provides an alternative explanation that makes the conclusion less probable. [AAMC CARS Skill 2]

mol_bio.q: Which enzyme synthesizes the new DNA strand during replication?
mol_bio.exp: DNA Pol III (prokaryotes) is the main replicative polymerase, extending the new strand 5'→3'. It cannot start new chains — primase first makes an RNA primer. [AAMC FC 1B]

mol_bio.q: The central dogma of molecular biology is:
mol_bio.exp: DNA is transcribed → mRNA, which is translated → protein. Reverse transcriptase (in retroviruses) can go RNA → DNA — an exception to the classic dogma. [AAMC FC 1B]

mol_bio.q: Which mutation type is most likely to be silent?
mol_bio.exp: The genetic code is degenerate — multiple codons encode the same amino acid. Synonymous (silent) mutations change the codon but not the amino acid or protein function. [AAMC FC 1B]

mol_bio.q: In a testcross, the unknown organism is crossed with:
mol_bio.exp: Testcross with homozygous recessive (aa): if offspring are all dominant phenotype → unknown is AA; if 50% dominant + 50% recessive → unknown is Aa. [AAMC FC 2A]

mol_bio.q: Which RNA molecule carries amino acids to the ribosome?
mol_bio.exp: tRNA has an anticodon complementary to mRNA codons and is aminoacylated (charged) with the corresponding amino acid by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases. [AAMC FC 1B]

mol_bio.q: Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium requires all of the following EXCEPT:
mol_bio.exp: H-W equilibrium: p² + 2pq + q² = 1. Requires: random mating, no mutation, large population, no migration, and NO natural selection (no selective pressure). [AAMC FC 2A]

mol_bio.q: Starting from AUG, how many amino acids does 5'-CUGCCAAUGUGCUAAUCGCG-3' encode?
mol_bio.exp: Scan for AUG: ...A-A-U-G-U-G-C-U-A-A → AUG (Met=AA1), UGC (Cys=AA2), UAA = stop. Polypeptide = 2 amino acids. [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 2; FC 1B]

mol_bio.q: In the lac operon, transcription is induced when:
opts: Lactose is absent and repressor binds operator
Lactose is present, allolactose inactivates the repressor
Glucose is high regardless of lactose
mol_bio.exp: Allolactose (lactose metabolite) binds the lacI repressor, causing conformational change → repressor cannot bind operator → RNA polymerase transcribes structural genes. [AAMC FC 1B]

mol_bio.q: PCR (polymerase chain reaction) requires all EXCEPT:
mol_bio.exp: PCR components: template DNA, primers (forward + reverse), Taq polymerase (heat-stable), dNTPs, and a thermal cycler. Ribosomes are used in translation, not PCR. [AAMC FC 1B]
SDS denatures proteins and coats them uniformly negative. In the electric field, they migrate solely by molecular weight (smaller = faster). [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 3; FC 1A]

opts: Each daughter DNA has one original and one newly synthesized strand
Replication only starts from one origin
mol_bio.exp: Meselson & Stahl (1958): ¹⁵N/¹⁴N experiment proved semiconservative replication. Each daughter double helix has one parental and one new strand. [AAMC FC 1B]

mol_bio.q: The lytic cycle differs from the lysogenic cycle in that it:
opts: Integrates viral DNA into the host genome
Immediately replicates and lyses the host cell
Causes no harm to the host
mol_bio.exp: Lytic cycle: virus enters → hijacks host machinery → produces progeny virions → lyses (destroys) host cell. Lysogenic cycle = integration (prophage) and dormancy until induction. [AAMC FC 2B]

mol_bio.q: Which process is responsible for generating genetic diversity during meiosis?
mol_bio.exp: Crossing over in prophase I of meiosis exchanges segments between homologous chromosomes, generating new allele combinations. Independent assortment (meiosis I) also contributes. [AAMC FC 2A]

cell_bio.exp: 3 Na⁺ pumped OUT, 2 K⁺ pumped IN per ATP hydrolyzed. Creates the electrochemical gradient (resting potential ≈ −70 mV) essential for nerve and muscle function. [AAMC FC 3A]
Mitosis: 1 diploid (2n) cell → 2 diploid daughter cells with identical genetic content. Used for growth, repair, and asexual reproduction. [AAMC FC 1C]

opts: Modifies, packages, and sorts proteins for their destinations
cell_bio.exp: Golgi (cis→trans): receives proteins from ER, modifies them (glycosylation, etc.), and routes them to secretion, lysosomes, or plasma membrane. [AAMC FC 2A]

cell_bio.q: Which organelle is the site of aerobic respiration (TCA cycle + ETC)?
cell_bio.exp: Mitochondria: TCA cycle occurs in the matrix; ETC + ATP synthase are on the inner mitochondrial membrane. [AAMC FC 3B]

cell_bio.q: In order, the phases of the cell cycle are:
cell_bio.exp: Interphase: G1 (growth) → S (DNA synthesis/replication) → G2 (prep for division). Then M phase (mitosis + cytokinesis). [AAMC FC 1C]

cell_bio.q: Gs protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) activation leads to:
opts: Adenylyl cyclase → ↑cAMP → protein kinase A (PKA) activation
cell_bio.exp: Gs-GPCR: ligand binds receptor → Gs activates adenylyl cyclase → cAMP increases → PKA phosphorylates downstream targets. Classic second-messenger cascade. [AAMC FC 2A]

cell_bio.q: Which transport requires a protein carrier but NO ATP?
cell_bio.exp: Facilitated diffusion: uses channel or carrier proteins, moves down concentration gradient, no energy required. Examples: GLUT transporters (glucose), aquaporins (water). [AAMC FC 3A]

cell_bio.q: Apoptosis differs from necrosis in that apoptosis:
opts: Causes cellular swelling and membrane rupture
Is programmed, orderly, and does not cause inflammation
Releases cellular contents causing tissue damage
cell_bio.exp: Apoptosis: programmed cell death — cell shrinks, DNA fragments (laddering), apoptotic bodies form, phagocytes clear debris without inflammation. Necrosis = uncontrolled, inflammatory. [AAMC FC 1C]

opts: Directly uses ATP to transport glucose
Uses the Na⁺ electrochemical gradient established by the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase
Moves glucose against both its own and Na⁺ gradients using ATP
cell_bio.exp: Secondary active transport: couples downhill movement of Na⁺ (established by the primary Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase) to drive uphill transport of glucose. ATP is used indirectly. [AAMC FC 3A]

cell_bio.q: Microtubules form the mitotic spindle and are composed of:
cell_bio.exp: Microtubules = polymerized α/β-tubulin dimers. They form the mitotic spindle, cilia, flagella, and serve as tracks for kinesin and dynein motor proteins. [AAMC FC 2A]

cell_bio.q: Which cell junction allows direct communication between adjacent cells?
cell_bio.exp: Gap junctions: connexin protein channels connect the cytoplasm of adjacent cells directly, allowing ions and small molecules to pass. Important for cardiac and smooth muscle coordination. [AAMC FC 2A]

organ_sys.q: The Frank-Starling law states that stroke volume:
opts: Increases with greater ventricular preload (end-diastolic volume)
organ_sys.exp: Frank-Starling: increased ventricular filling stretches myocytes → more forceful contraction (optimal actin-myosin overlap) → greater stroke volume. [AAMC FC 4B]

organ_sys.q: The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) is the primary site for:
opts: Concentration of urine by countercurrent multiplication
organ_sys.exp: PCT reabsorbs ~65–70% of filtered Na⁺, water, glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate isosmotically. The collecting duct is where aldosterone and ADH act for fine-tuning. [AAMC FC 4C]

organ_sys.q: ACTH stimulates the adrenal cortex to produce:
organ_sys.exp: HPA axis: CRH (hypothalamus) → ACTH (anterior pituitary) → cortisol (adrenal cortex zona fasciculata). Cortisol is the primary glucocorticoid. [AAMC FC 3C]

organ_sys.q: During rapid depolarization of an action potential, which ion rushes in?
organ_sys.exp: Voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open → rapid Na⁺ influx → membrane depolarizes from −70 mV to approximately +30 mV. K⁺ efflux then causes repolarization. [AAMC FC 3A]

opts: Decreased pH reducing hemoglobin's O₂ affinity, shifting the dissociation curve right
The cooperative binding of O₂ to hemoglobin
organ_sys.exp: Bohr effect: increased CO₂/H⁺ (decreased pH) in active tissues stabilizes the T-state (low-affinity) hemoglobin → O₂ released to tissues. Curve shifts right. [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 4; FC 3B]

opts: Voluntary movement, balance, and fine motor control
organ_sys.exp: Cerebellum: coordinates movement precision, balance, and motor learning. Damage causes ataxia (uncoordinated movement). The medulla handles autonomic functions. [AAMC FC 3B]

opts: Increasing Na⁺ reabsorption in the collecting duct → water follows → increased blood volume
Inhibiting renin release from the kidney
organ_sys.exp: Aldosterone (mineralocorticoid) upregulates ENaC and Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase in the collecting duct → Na⁺ (and osmotically, water) reabsorption → blood volume → blood pressure. [AAMC FC 3C]
Chief cells → pepsinogen (inactive). Parietal cells → HCl (activates pepsinogen → pepsin) + intrinsic factor (needed for B12 absorption). [AAMC FC 3C]
Adaptive immunity: T cells (cell-mediated, MHC-restricted) and B cells (humoral, produce antibodies). Neutrophils and macrophages are innate immune cells. [AAMC FC 2B]

organ_sys.q: The functional unit of the kidney is the:
organ_sys.exp: Each kidney has ~1 million nephrons. Each nephron: glomerulus → Bowman's capsule → PCT → loop of Henle → DCT → collecting duct. [AAMC FC 4C]

organ_sys.q: During inhalation, air enters the lungs because:
opts: The diaphragm pushes up, increasing lung pressure
The diaphragm contracts downward, expanding thoracic volume, reducing intrathoracic pressure below atmospheric
organ_sys.exp: Diaphragm + external intercostals contract → thoracic volume increases → intrapulmonary pressure drops below atmospheric → air flows in (Boyle's Law: P₁V₁ = P₂V₂). [AAMC FC 4B]

organ_sys.q: Which vessel carries oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart?
organ_sys.exp: Pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from lungs → left atrium. Pulmonary arteries carry deoxygenated blood from right ventricle → lungs. (Veins carry blood TO the heart.) [AAMC FC 4B]

opts: Shaping behavior through rewards and punishments
Pairing a neutral stimulus with an unconditioned stimulus until the NS alone produces a response
behavior.exp: Pavlov: bell (NS/CS) + food (UCS) → salivation (UCR/CR). The NS becomes a CS by temporal association with the UCS. [AAMC FC 7C]

behavior.q: Operant conditioning differs from classical conditioning in that operant:
opts: Uses consequences (reinforcement/punishment) to change voluntary behavior
behavior.exp: Skinner's operant conditioning: behavior is voluntary and shaped by consequences. Positive/negative reinforcement increase behavior; punishment decreases it. [AAMC FC 7C]

behavior.q: Maslow's hierarchy of needs (bottom to top) is:
behavior.exp: Maslow: lower needs must be met before higher ones. Physiological (food, water, shelter) → Safety → Love/Belonging → Esteem → Self-actualization. [AAMC FC 7A]

opts: Reward, motivation, and the mesolimbic pathway
behavior.exp: Dopamine: primary neurotransmitter of the mesolimbic (reward) pathway. Implicated in motivation, pleasure, and addiction. Serotonin is associated with mood; epinephrine with fight-or-flight. [AAMC FC 7A]

behavior.q: The fight-or-flight response is driven by the:
behavior.exp: Sympathetic activation (epinephrine, norepinephrine from adrenal medulla): ↑HR, ↑BP, dilated pupils, bronchodilation, decreased digestion. Parasympathetic = 'rest and digest.' [AAMC FC 7A]

behavior.q: In a social loafing study (individual vs. group task), the independent and dependent variables are:
opts: IV = task type; DV = group vs. individual
IV = group productivity; DV = individual contribution
IV = working alone vs. in group; DV = each participant's individual contribution
IV = working alone vs. in group; DV = the task type
behavior.exp: IV = what is manipulated (group vs. individual condition); DV = what is measured (each person's effort/contribution). [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 3; FC 7B]

behavior.q: In a study, salivation to lemon juice decreases over repeated trials, then recovers when lime juice is used. This demonstrates:
behavior.exp: Habituation = reduced responding to repeated stimulus. Dishabituation = response recovery when stimulus changes. [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 1; FC 7C]

behavior.q: Erikson's 'Identity vs. Role Confusion' stage occurs during:
behavior.exp: Erikson Stage 5 (adolescence): core task is forming a personal identity. Success → integrated sense of self; failure → role confusion and uncertainty about one's place in society. [AAMC FC 7A]

behavior.q: Schachter-Singer two-factor theory proposes that emotion requires:
opts: Physiological arousal + cognitive labeling of that arousal
behavior.exp: Two-factor theory: undifferentiated physiological arousal + a situational cognitive label = a specific emotion. The same physiological state can become fear, excitement, or anger depending on context. [AAMC FC 7A]

opts: Reverting to childlike behavior under stress
Attributing one's own unacceptable thoughts or feelings to others
Channeling impulses into socially acceptable behaviors
Refusing to consciously acknowledge a painful reality
behavior.exp: Projection (Freud): unconsciously attributing unacceptable internal feelings to another person (e.g., an angry person insisting others are the hostile ones). [AAMC FC 7A]

behavior.q: Which schedule of reinforcement produces the highest response rate and greatest resistance to extinction?
behavior.exp: Variable ratio schedule (e.g., slot machines): reinforcement after an unpredictable number of responses → highest and most persistent response rate. The unpredictability prevents extinction. [AAMC FC 7C]

cognition.q: Working memory (Baddeley's model) is best described as:
opts: Temporary active manipulation of information in consciousness
cognition.exp: Working memory: limited-capacity, short-duration active system. Includes phonological loop, visuospatial sketchpad, and central executive. [AAMC FC 6B]

cognition.q: The availability heuristic leads people to:
opts: Estimate probability by how easily examples come to mind
cognition.exp: Availability heuristic (Tversky & Kahneman): people judge frequency/probability by ease of recall. Vivid, recent, or dramatic events are overestimated. [AAMC FC 6B]

cognition.q: Which sleep stage is most associated with vivid dreaming and memory consolidation?
cognition.exp: REM (rapid eye movement) sleep: brain is active, muscles are paralyzed (atonia), vivid dreams occur, and emotional/procedural memories are consolidated. [AAMC FC 6B]

cognition.q: Piaget's formal operational stage (~age 12+) is characterized by:
cognition.exp: Formal operational: ability to reason about abstract concepts, hypothetical scenarios, and systematically test hypotheses — the most advanced cognitive stage. [AAMC FC 7A]

cognition.q: Weber's Law states that the just-noticeable difference (JND):
opts: Is constant regardless of stimulus intensity
Is proportional to the magnitude of the original stimulus
Depends only on the type of sensory modality
cognition.exp: Weber's Law: ΔI/I = k (Weber fraction). The JND is a constant proportion of the original stimulus. Heavier objects require bigger changes to notice a difference. [AAMC FC 6A]

cognition.q: Long-term potentiation (LTP) is the cellular mechanism for:
opts: Synaptic strengthening underlying learning and memory
cognition.exp: LTP: repeated high-frequency stimulation → AMPA receptor insertion + NMDA receptor activation → increased synaptic efficacy. This synaptic strengthening is the cellular basis of learning and long-term memory. [AAMC FC 7A]

cognition.q: Retrograde amnesia is the loss of:
opts: Ability to form new memories after an injury
cognition.exp: Retrograde amnesia: loss of memories acquired before the brain injury. Anterograde amnesia: inability to form NEW memories after the injury (classic example: patient H.M. after hippocampectomy). [AAMC FC 6B]

cognition.q: Fluid intelligence differs from crystallized intelligence in that it:
opts: Peaks in young adulthood and declines with age
Is stored primarily in semantic memory
cognition.exp: Fluid intelligence (Cattell): novel problem-solving, abstract reasoning — peaks ~20s, declines with age. Crystallized intelligence: accumulated knowledge/vocabulary — stable or increases with age. [AAMC FC 6B]

cognition.q: Signal detection theory separates perceptual performance into:
cognition.exp: SDT: d' (d-prime) = sensitivity (ability to distinguish signal from noise); β = response bias (willingness to respond 'yes'). This separates perceptual ability from decision-making strategy. [AAMC FC 6A]

opts: Failure to notice unexpected visible stimuli when attention is focused elsewhere
Visual neglect after parietal lobe damage
cognition.exp: Inattentional blindness: when observers focus on a task, salient but unexpected events are often not consciously perceived — attention is selective and resource-limited. [AAMC FC 6A]

sociology.q: Social mobility based on achieved status (education, career) characterizes:
sociology.exp: Class systems allow social mobility based on achieved characteristics. Caste systems (e.g., India's traditional system) are based on ascribed (birth) status with little/no mobility. [AAMC FC 9A]

sociology.q: Parsons' 'sick role' means that ill individuals:
opts: Are exempt from normal duties but are obligated to seek treatment
sociology.exp: Parsons' sick role (functionalist): (1) exempted from normal responsibilities, (2) not blamed, (3) must want to get well, (4) must seek competent help. [AAMC FC 9B]

sociology.q: The process of internalizing a culture's norms and values from birth is called:
sociology.exp: Enculturation: absorbing the culture one is born into. Acculturation = adapting to a new culture (without fully losing the original). Socialization is broader. [AAMC FC 8A]

opts: Income, education, housing, neighborhood, and access to healthcare
sociology.exp: Social determinants of health (SDOH): the conditions in which people live, work, and age — income, education, housing, food security, healthcare access — are the primary drivers of health disparities. [AAMC FC 10A]

opts: A deeply discrediting attribute that reduces one's social identity
A positive social label given to professionals
sociology.exp: Goffman (1963): stigma = a 'spoiled identity' — a mark of disgrace that reduces a person from a full, whole person to a discounted or lesser one in social interactions. [AAMC FC 8B]

opts: Cultural practices converge globally over time
Cultural distinctions of elite classes will be more socially valued
sociology.exp: Cultural capital (Bourdieu): knowledge, skills, and tastes associated with elite/dominant classes are institutionally valued, reproducing social stratification across generations. [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 2; FC 10A]

sociology.q: Conflict theory views society as primarily characterized by:
opts: Competition and struggle over scarce resources and power
Gradual adaptive evolution of social structures
sociology.exp: Conflict theory (Marx, Weber): society is structured by conflict between groups competing for resources, wealth, and power. Contrasts with functionalism (consensus) and symbolic interactionism. [AAMC FC 9A]

opts: Meaning-making through symbols in everyday face-to-face interaction
sociology.exp: Symbolic interactionism (Mead, Blumer): micro-level perspective — people create shared meaning through symbols, language, and social interaction. Associated with stigma, sick role, and illness experience. [AAMC FC 9A]

opts: Earning below the median household income
Lacking sufficient resources for basic survival needs (food, shelter, clothing)
Being in the bottom income quintile
sociology.exp: Absolute poverty = unable to meet basic survival needs. Relative poverty = below a society's average standard of living. An important distinction for health disparities research. [AAMC FC 10A]

opts: Automatic unconscious attitudes that affect judgments and behavior
Institutional policies that disadvantage minority groups
sociology.exp: Implicit bias: unconscious associations about social groups influencing behavior, even when a person explicitly rejects those biases. Measured by tools like the Implicit Association Test (IAT). [AAMC FC 8B]

sociology.q: Which sociological paradigm is MOST consistent with studying how a patient's rare disease affects their day-to-day social interactions and sense of self?
sociology.exp: Symbolic interactionism: focuses on how individuals construct meaning through small-scale interactions — most relevant to illness experience, stigma, and self-concept. [AAMC Sample Question, Skill 2; FC 9A]

research.q: An RCT is the gold standard for establishing causality because:
opts: Randomization controls for known and unknown confounders
It uses the largest sample sizes
research.exp: Randomization distributes both known and unknown confounders equally between groups, allowing causal conclusions to be drawn. [AAMC FC Research Methods]

research.q: A Type I error (α) occurs when:
opts: A real effect is missed (false negative)
A true null hypothesis is incorrectly rejected (false positive)
The wrong statistical test is used
The sample size is too small
research.exp: Type I error = false positive: concluding an effect exists when it does not. Typically set at α = 0.05 (5% chance of false positive). [AAMC FC Research Methods]
r ranges from −1 to +1. r = −0.85 = strong negative: as one variable increases, the other decreases substantially. r² = 0.72 → 72% of variance shared. [AAMC FC Research Methods]

research.q: The empirical rule for a normal distribution states that ~68% of data falls within:
research.exp: Empirical rule: ±1 SD = ~68%, ±2 SD = ~95%, ±3 SD = ~99.7%. Critical for interpreting standard deviations and z-scores. [AAMC FC Research Methods, Skill 4]

research.q: Case-control studies are best suited for studying:
opts: Rare diseases with long latency periods
Incidence of new diseases over time
research.exp: Case-control: starts with cases (disease+) and matched controls (disease−), then looks back at exposures. Efficient for rare diseases. Cannot calculate incidence. [AAMC FC Research Methods]

opts: Failing to detect a real effect (false negative)
A sampling error from too large a sample
research.exp: Type II error (β) = false negative: failing to detect a real effect. Statistical power (1 − β) is the probability of correctly detecting a true effect. Larger sample size reduces β. [AAMC FC Research Methods]

opts: There is a 95% chance the true value is in THIS specific interval
If the study were repeated many times, 95% of such intervals would contain the true value
95% of sample data falls in the interval
The null is rejected at the 5% level — always
research.exp: Frequentist interpretation of CI: over many repetitions of the study, 95% of constructed intervals would contain the true population parameter. It does NOT mean 95% probability the true value is in THIS interval. [AAMC FC Research Methods, Skill 4]

opts: Only participants don't know their treatment assignment
Neither participants nor the researchers interacting with them know treatment assignment
The study uses no control group
research.exp: Double-blind: eliminates both subject expectation effects (placebo) and researcher bias. Both the participant and the researchers who interact with/assess them are blinded to treatment. [AAMC FC Research Methods]

opts: Generalizability of results to other populations
Whether the study accurately measures the causal relationship between IV and DV
Cultural relevance of the measures used
research.exp: Internal validity: confidence that changes in DV are caused by the IV (not confounders). External validity = generalizability. Reliability = consistency. [AAMC FC Research Methods, Skill 3]

research.q: An IRB (Institutional Review Board) primarily protects:
opts: The rights, safety, and welfare of human research participants
research.exp: IRBs implement the Belmont Report principles: Respect for persons (informed consent), Beneficence (minimize harm, maximize benefit), Justice (fair participant selection). [AAMC FC Research Methods, Skill 3]

research.q: Which measure of central tendency is most affected by extreme outliers?
research.exp: The mean is pulled toward extreme values (outliers). The median is resistant to outliers. This is why income is often reported as median household income rather than mean. [AAMC FC Research Methods, Skill 4]
